claim: All cats are mammals. Tigers belong to the cat family. Therefore, tigers are mammals

supporting.text: All cats are mammals, as they belong to the biological family Felidae, which is classified under the class Mammalia.

attacks.text: All cats are mammals, as they belong to the biological family Felidae, which is classified under the class Mammalia.
Some members of the Felidae family, such as extinct species, may not fit the modern definition of mammals due to evolutionary differences.
Modern taxonomy strictly classifies all extant and extinct Felidae species under Mammalia, based on shared derived characteristics like mammary glands and hair.

supporting.text: Tigers are members of the cat family (Felidae), which is a subset of mammals, confirming that tigers are mammals.

attacks.text: Tigers are members of the cat family (Felidae), which is a subset of mammals, confirming that tigers are mammals.
Some biologists argue that the classification of Felidae as mammals is outdated and should be reconsidered based on genetic differences.
Mainstream taxonomy overwhelmingly supports Felidae as mammals, with genetic studies consistently confirming this classification.
If a tiger were discovered with non-mammalian traits, such as laying eggs, it would challenge the assertion that all tigers are mammals.
No known tiger species exhibit non-mammalian traits, making this hypothetical scenario irrelevant to current biological classification.

supporting.text: Mammals are characterized by features such as mammary glands and hair, which are present in all members of the cat family, including tigers.

attacks.text: Mammals are characterized by features such as mammary glands and hair, which are present in all members of the cat family, including tigers.
Some genetic mutations in tigers could theoretically result in the absence of mammary glands or hair, making them non-mammalian.
Genetic mutations causing the absence of mammary glands or hair in tigers are extremely rare and not observed in nature, so they do not invalidate the general classification.
The definition of mammals is not solely based on mammary glands and hair; other features like three middle ear bones are also required, which might not be present in all cat family members.
All members of the cat family, including tigers, have been scientifically confirmed to possess three middle ear bones, fulfilling the mammalian criteria.

supporting.text: Scientific taxonomy classifies tigers (Panthera tigris) under the order Carnivora, which is part of the class Mammalia, supporting the claim.

attacks.text: Scientific taxonomy classifies tigers (Panthera tigris) under the order Carnivora, which is part of the class Mammalia, supporting the claim.

Modern taxonomy is based on extensive genetic and morphological evidence, making it a reliable scientific framework.
